awd_titl_txt: High Reynolds Number Turbulence Research in Cryogenic Helium
awd_abstract_narration:
Many flows in nature, including those generated by aircraft, ships, and the atmosphere, have extremely high Reynolds numbers.  The Reynolds number is the ratio of flow's inertial forces relative to viscous forces, and it determines important flow properties such as turbulence.  Understanding flows with extremely high Reynolds numbers will increase efficiency in practical vehicle applications and improve understanding of the climate.  However, high Reynolds-number flow in conventional fluids like air and water occurs on a relatively large scale thus is difficult to study on the laboratory scale. Fortunately, high Reynolds number flows can be achieved using lower-density fluids such as cryogenic helium-4 in, for example, a small-scale laboratory pipe flow experiment. But to unlock the full potential of cryogenic helium-4, suitable flow measurement tools to quantify the turbulence are also required. The proposed research will therefore develop advanced molecular tagging velocity measurement techniques and apply the technique to high Reynolds number cryogenic helium pipe flow. In terms of educational opportunities, the joint College of Engineering operated by Florida State University and Florida A&M University will be leveraged to recruit under-represented minorities to participate in the project. The PI and the co-PI's groups will also contribute educational demonstrations for public open-house events at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory and at the Florida Center for Advanced Aero-Propulsion.

The scientific goal of this project is to develop a state-of-the-art molecular tagging velocimetry technique for cryogenic helium and to demonstrate its usefulness by applying it in the study of high Reynolds number cryogenic helium pipe flow. Sophisticated patterns of the molecular tracer lines will be created by splitting and focusing a femtosecond laser beam in liquid helium. Advanced pattern-tracking algorithms will be incorporated, and the spatial and temporal resolutions of the tracer imaging process will be optimized. These developments will unlock the full potential of cryogenic helium in turbulence research and model testing. The planned study on high Reynolds number pipe flows in helium will allow an independent examination of the near-wall velocity field and the associated von K?rm?n coefficient, which may help resolve existing controversies regarding the universality of this coefficient. Also, new knowledge about the near-wall spatial velocity correlations will be produced by tracking the tracer lines created perpendicular to the wall. Furthermore, by measuring the pressure drop along the pipe, reliable friction factor data for high Reynolds number flows will be obtained, which will benefit the design of various engineering systems that exhibit high Reynolds numbers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In the award period, our team successfully restored the Liquid Helium Flow Visualization Facility (LHFVF) at the Maglab. This facility allows the generation of liquid helium flows in a pipe with 2 cm diamater and 3 m in length. Taking advantage of the extremely small kinematic viscosity of liquid helium (LHe), we generated fully developed turbulent pipe flows with Reynolds (Re) numbers exceeding 10^6. Then, a molecular tagging velocity (MTV) technique was implemented to create thin molecular tracer lines close to and perpendicular to the pipe bottom wall. By fluorescence imaging of the tracer line, we successfully measured the near-wall velocity profile in the superfluid fluid phase of liquid helium (He II). During the lab shutdown caused by the pandemic, we also conducted a modeling project on designing a novel magnetic-levitation-based low-gravity simulator (MLS) for future fluid dynamics research in near-zero gravity. Our research has led to a few journal publications as well as two papers in preparation. The major outcomes are summarized below.

 

Intellectual Merit:

1) LHFVF development: It has been well known that both normal LHe (He I) and He II have extremely small kinematic viscosity, which makes them valuable fluid materials in high Re turbulence research and modeling. However, flow facilities that could generate controllable and well-defined turbulent flows in LHe are scarce. More problematically, there lacked reliable and accurate quantitative flow measurement tools for LHe. Our team not only restored the LHFVF but also developed a novel double-line MTV optical system. The combination of the LHFVF and the double-line MTV now allow quantitative measurements of near-wall velocity profile and two-point velocity correlations in high Re pipe flows. This system unlocks the potential of LHe in fluid dynamics research and model testing applications.

 

2) Law-of-the-wall in He II: One of the milestone achievements in turbulence research is the discovery of the "law of the wall", which states that the mean velocity of a turbulent flow near a solid wall takes a universal logarithmic form at sufficiently high Reynolds numbers. However, there is no existing knowledge on what the law-of-the-wall in a superfluid may look like. Specifically, in He II, there are two miscible fluid components, i.e., a viscous normal fluid satisfying the no-slip boundary condition on the wall and an inviscid superfluid that is not restricted by this condition. Although past research suggested that the two fluids can become strongly coupled by a mutual friction in mechanically generated flows, it is not clear whether this mutual friction is effective enough to couple the two fluids in the thin boundary layer where a strong velocity gradient exists. Our team applied the MTV technique and successfully measured the near-wall velocity profile in He II pipe flows with Re numbers exceeding 10^6. For the first time, we showed that the log-law velocity profile also exists in He II, but the Karman coefficient in the log-law formula appears to differ from that in classical fluids. These results not only expand our knowledge of turbulence in general but also provides a foundation for theoretical modeling of the friction factor in He II pipe flows.

 

3) Design of novel MLS: Low-gravity environment is known to have profound impact on the dynamics of fluids. Developing ground-based low-gravity simulators will allow convenient and systematic research on the effects of gravity. Among various simulator systems, the MLS has received long-lasting interest due to its easily adjustable gravity and practically unlimited operation time. However, a recognized issue with MLSs is their highly nonuniform force field. For a solenoid MLS, the functional volume, where the net force results in an acceleration less than 1% of the Earth's gravity g, is typically a few microliters or less. We proposed a MLS design that integrates a superconducting magnet with a gradient-field Maxwell coil. Through an optimization analysis, we showed that an unprecedented functional volume of over 4000 microliters can be achieved in a compact coil with a diameter of 8 cm. When the current in this MLS is reduced to emulate the gravity on Mars, a functional volume exceeding 20,000 microliters can be achieved. Such a design may break new ground for future low-gravity fluid dynamics research.

 

Broader Impacts:

Our research program has engaged undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers. The training that these students and postdocs received makes them well prepared for their career. The undergraduate students mostly continued to pursue their advance degrees, including one recruited by FAMU, a historically black university. Our team members have also contributed in various educational and outreach activities at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory. The research results obtained from this program have been disseminated at a number of international conferences and workshops and were also included in a short course on Cryogenics presented by the PI at the at the 2020 International Applied Superconductivity Conference.


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: Wei Guo
